thread.title: Milford Mill joyously advances to sectional final, 68-55
thread.title_full: Milford Mill joyously advances to sectional final, 68-55

author: Katherine Dunn
title: Milford Mill joyously advances to sectional final, 68-55
text:
The polls through Sundayâ€™s events Boys basketball No. School Record Prev. 1. Perry Hall 21-2 1 2. Patterson 21-3 2 3. Mount Saint Joseph 32-3 3 4. Poly 16-7 4 5. Mount Carmel 25-9 5 6. Lake Clifton 19-4 6 7. McDonogh 20-10 7 8. Woodlawn 19-4 9 9. Dunbar 18-5 10 10. Old Mill 21-2 11 11. John Carroll... (The Baltimore Sun) 
"I told them, 'See how many possessions are in this game. We don't need to rush. Do not go to the corners. They're trapping. Be ready to move the ball and move people. We ain't trying to go to the basket unless we have a wide open layup. Move the ball,'" McAliley said. 
The Millers answered with 10 straight points, helped by three Poly turnovers. Pollard and Jone Ayers, who finished with 17 points each, each hit a 3-pointer and a short bucket to boost the lead to 47-36. Milford finished the quarter on a 15-1 run, taking a 52-37 lead on Hughes' three-point play. 
Pollard said her team seized the momentum thanks to, "Everybody's encouragement. We just had to keep it going. Once we got it going, we all got going." 
Poly came roaring back to start the final quarter. The Engineers opened the quarter with a nine-point run. Galloway had two terrific assists in that run, including one off a steal to pull her team within 52-46 with 5:06 left. 
McAliley called another timeout and Ayers stopped the Poly momentum with a driving layup. 
The Engineers rallied again when Porter hit a layup and Deierra Weems added two free throws to cut the Millers' lead to 56-52. Poly appeared to cut the lead to two when Galloway hit Porter for a layup, but Porter was called for traveling. 
Ayers scored the next five points, and the Engineers began fouling. The Millers hit seven of nine free throws in the final 58 seconds. 
The Millers, who won back-to-back state championships in 2014 and 2015, will forget about their celebration and begin focusing on Franklin, a fellow Baltimore County team they did not play during the regular season. 
"On to the next one. On to the next one. We just keep playing," Pollard said.
